ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: Depending on the reading assignment, I would spend anywhere from one to four hours for reading article(s) and one to two days for reading books. There were a three books assigned for the semester and the rest were articles.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Overall, the course was very interesting. I enjoyed the readings and the in-class discussions. Of course, there were some topics that were more interesting to me than others. The major strength of the class was that we were able to learn about important historical epidemics in Asia from a very knowledgeable professor. One of the weaknesses of the class was that the seminars did not seem very structured. However, being a seminar, the focus is on class discussion rather than lecture.

the course provides you an overall understanding of the major infectious disease outbreaks in Asian and helps you view it from different standpoints. The final presentations benefits students by providing a platform for sharing their ideas.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: William C. Summers  Professor Summers is very knowledgeable in both the medical and historical fields. He always had interesting bits of information to share with the class. As previously mentioned, perhaps a more structured seminar discussion would have made the class even better.

Instructor: William C. Summers  Professor Summers has profound knowledge in history in disease outbreaks and can integrate clinical and epidemiological knowledge into the class which makes the understanding of disease outbreak more concrete and fun.It will be even better if powerpoint that conclude the keypoints mentioned in class can be provided online and can be used as a future reference.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This class focuses on specific epidemics in Asia, from cholera in India to SARS in China and even the Japanese biological warfare. Overall, the class was interesting and I would recommended the class to those who are interested in exploring historical epidemics in Asia.
I would definitely recommend this course. Provides an interesting look of how infectious diseases have shaped international relations in Asia.

yes, good course to take if you are interested in infectious disease especially the investigations of disease outbreak. it helps to broaden your horizon and pave the way for future infectious disease study.
